event: Thai F-16 jets dropped MK-82 bombs near Preah Vihear Temple, escalating the border conflict and displacing over 32,558 people.
Ceasefire signed to halt the conflict, but Thai forces captured 20 unarmed Cambodian troops near Oddar Meanchey, displacing 39,546 more.

ASEAN Military Observer Group, led by Malaysia’s Colonel Nazlee Bin Abdul Rahim, departed Phnom Penh to monitor ceasefire in Oddar Meanchey and Preah Vihear for two weeks following the July 28 agreement.
Cambodia notified Thailand of the ASEAN Observer Team’s visit to Oddar Meanchey and Preah Vihear from August 3 to monitor ceasefire implementation.
Cambodia reported Thai military plans to attack from Tamone Thom to Anseh, breaching the July 28 ceasefire, prompting international appeals.
Cambodia-Thailand GBC Secretariat delegation arrived in Malaysia for meetings from August 4-7 to enhance ceasefire efforts.
Thai forces entered An Ses with excavators and laid barbed wire, violating the ceasefire, despite Cambodia’s sovereignty claims.
GBC Secretariat, led by Major General Sin Sokha, met in Kuala Lumpur to strengthen ceasefire credibility ahead of the August 7 meeting.
Thai forces used excavators and dug trenches in An Ses, prompting Cambodia to demand withdrawal, with discussions ongoing.
Thai-installed barbed wire in An Ses was removed by 5:30 PM after negotiations, though tensions persist.
